item.title: Los efectos del alcohol en el cuerpo
item.description: Desde el momento en que tomas un sorbo, la bebida empieza a influir en tu biología. He aquí una mirada desde el interior.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith and Montse Galbany

item.title: EE. UU. se prepara para un posible enfrentamiento militar con Irán
item.description: Mientras Trump analiza sus opciones bélicas si la diplomacia no logra resolver sus disputas con Irán, el Pentágono está aprovechando el tiempo para terminar de construir sus fuerzas ofensivas.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Personas en Teherán caminan sobre banderas estadounidenses e israelíes durante una marcha para conmemorar el 47 aniversario de la revolución islámica de Irán. Altos funcionarios dijeron que Trump no había decidido si atacaría Irán.

item.title: How Peter Biar Ajak, a Sudanese Peace Activist, Was Caught Plotting a Coup
item.description: Peter Biar Ajak, a democracy advocate, was convicted of conspiring to buy and export weapons for a revolt in South Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Leah Millis/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Peter Biar Ajak after returning to the United States in 2020. A federal court in Arizona sentenced him to prison last week after he pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate U.S. weapons export laws.

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

media:content.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.description: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin

media:content.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation complex in Shanghai. The Chinese government has spent more than $150 billion on its push to make cutting-edge chips at home.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 14, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 14, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: 30 Grand Romantic Gestures to Sweep You Off Your Feet
item.description: Quotation of the Day for February, 14, 2026.

item.title: Casey Wasserman Will Sell Entertainment Agency Amid Epstein Files Fallout
item.description: Casey Wasserman, a Los Angeles entertainment executive and the head of the 2028 Olympic Games, has lost clients since his emails with Ghislaine Maxwell surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Ben Sisario and Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)

media:content.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The most recent trove of Epstein documents include flirtatious messages between Casey Wasserman and Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein’s longtime companion, while Mr. Wasserman was married with a young family.

item.title: See the Biggest Tricks From the Olympic Halfpipe, in Miniature
item.description: These animations show how the halfpipe competitions again raised the bar for what’s possible on a snowboard.
item.dc:creator: Alice Fang, Jon Huang, Matt Ruby, Eden Weingart and Yuhan Liu

media:content.media:credit: Alice Fang, Jon Huang, Matt Ruby, Eden Weingart and Yuhan Liu/The New York Times

item.title: Three Federal Officers Injured in Los Angeles Protests, D.H.S. Says
item.description: One Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer was injured after being hit in the head with a rock, and two Federal Protective Services officers were also injured, the department said.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

media:content.media:credit: Ted Soqui/Sipa, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Los Angeles students walked out of school and marched to the federal building to rally and protest against ICE on Friday.

item.title: Short Rows
item.description: David Karp’s puzzle is a lovely affair.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Aren’t you glad that you rose to the challenge of this Valentine’s Day puzzle?

item.title: 18 Days, 20 Lives: New Yorkers Who Didn’t Survive the Cold
item.description: Freezing days and nights claimed the lives of a grandmother, a dancer, a dispatcher and a man who lived among a colony of feral cats.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman, Nate Schweber, Mihir Zaveri, Shayla Colon and Elizabeth A. Harris

media:content.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Files Final Plans for White House Ballroom
item.description: The president is seeking quick approval despite legal challenges and backlash over his demolition of the East Wing.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The site of the demolished East Wing of the White House in Washington in December.

item.title: See How Ilia Malinin Fell From Podium in 2026 Men’s Figure Skating Final
item.description: Ilia Malinin took first place in the short program, but his error-filled routine in the free skate dropped him to eighth overall.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai, Weiyi Cai, Bora Erden, Lazaro Gamio, Jeré Longman, Joe Ward and Jeremy White

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Man Shot by N.Y.P.D. Charged With Attempted Assault as Mamdani Objects
item.description: Police have said that Jabez Chakraborty wielded a knife as they responded to a 911 call. His family has disputed parts of the account, insisting their son was not a threat and needed help.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

item.title: After a Misstep, Sheriff Says Persistence Will Solve the Nancy Guthrie Case
item.description: Investigators have recovered DNA from the home where the mother of “Today” show host Savannah Guthrie was abducted, but do not have a match. “We’re going to find this guy,” said Sheriff Chris Nanos.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sheriff Chris Nanos of Pima County, at his office in Tucson, Ariz., on Friday.

item.title: Consultants Offered Epstein Access to Top N.Y. Democrats if He Donated
item.description: Dynamic SRG repeatedly, and apparently unsuccessfully, asked the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein to donate to House races, Justice Department records show.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root and Bianca Pallaro

media:content.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Once a prominent donor to Democratic politicians, Jeffrey Epstein appears to have largely stopped giving money to campaigns after he was convicted of sex crimes in Florida in 2008.

item.title: ICE Agents Menaced Minnesota Protesters at Their Homes, Filings Say
item.description: Protesters in Minneapolis and St. Paul said in sworn statements that they were singled out by agents who demonstrated that they knew where they lived.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich

item.title: TK
item.description: TK

item.title: Judge Orders U.S. to Facilitate Return of College Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor said last month that ICE had made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler and Mattathias Schwartz

media:content.media:credit: Massdeportationdefense.Org, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza, a Massachusetts college student, was mistakenly deported in November to Honduras.

item.title: Jamelle Bouie on Pam Bondi’s Meltdown
item.description: On “The Opinions,” the columnist Jamelle Bouie says he thinks Pam Bondi’s combative testimony made her look like a “raving lunatic” — a reaction that Democrats were able to evoke for political gain.

item.title: Jury Deadlocked in Trial of Pro-Palestinian Demonstrators at Stanford
item.description: A judge declared a mistrial after a jury could not reach a verdict in a case in which five current and former students were charged with felonies.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

media:content.media:credit: Stephen Lam/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Students walked by a tent encampment in White Plaza at Stanford in 2024.

item.description: David Duda and Hong Liang use Microsoft Translator while shopping for groceries.

media:content.media:credit: Gilad Thaler/The New York Times

item.title: Judge Orders ICE to Let Clergy Give Communion to Detained Migrants on Ash Wednesday
item.description: A Catholic nonprofit and several clergy said immigration authorities had unlawfully blocked its members for months from providing pastoral care at an ICE facility in Broadview, Ill.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: People marched to the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Broadview, Ill., in October.

item.title: Florida Couple Arrested After Pickleball Match Turns Into a Brawl
item.description: The couple, who were banned for life from a country club in Port Orange, Fla., face felony battery charges after the fight, which involved 20 people, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Three people were injured during the fight at the Spruce Creek Country Club, and one of them was transported to a hospital, the Volusia Sheriff’s Office said.

item.title: La ONU condena las medidas de EE. UU. que paralizan los envíos de petróleo a Cuba
item.description: El alto comisionado de las Naciones Unidas para los Derechos Humanos ha instado a Estados Unidos a que levante las sanciones que impiden el suministro de petróleo a la isla.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Una calle de Santa Cruz del Norte, Cuba, este mes durante un apagón programado como parte del racionamiento energético.

item.title: Ebo Taylor, Musical Innovator of Highlife and Afrobeat, Dies at 90
item.description: Borrowing from jazz and African rhythms, he forged a singular style that helped define music in his native Ghana — and West Africa — for a generation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

media:content.media:credit: Samir Hussein/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Ebo Taylor performing in 2011 in Wiltshire, England. In his final years, he began to receive international recognition.

item.title: Trump Says Regime Change Would Be the ‘Best Thing’ for Iran
item.description: The president has been steadily building up U.S. military forces in the Middle East and threatening another strike on the country if the government does not abandon its nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump boarding Air Force One at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, on Friday.

item.title: ‘I Will Not Back Down’: Don Lemon Enters Not Guilty Plea
item.description: The journalist Don Lemon entered a not guilty plea on Friday to two accounts stemming from his participation in a protest at Cities Church in St. Paul, Minn., last month.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Don Lemon outside the federal courthouse in St. Paul, Minn., on Friday.

item.title: Measles Outbreak Hits Ave Maria University in Florida
item.description: More than 40 people have fallen ill at Ave Maria University, raising fears that college campuses may soon experience more measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth

media:content.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times

item.title: Why Are More Congress Members Retiring or Not Seeking Re-election in 2026?
item.description: For many senators and House members, the job isn’t what it used to be.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Takeaways From the Third Week of the Alexander Brothers Trial
item.description: More women who have accused the three brothers of sexual assault testified, and the judge replaced a juror who said he had already made his mind up about the case.
item.dc:creator: Kate Christobek

media:content.media:credit: Kent Edwards/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Pictures of brothers Alon, Oren and Tal Alexander at Federal Plaza in Manhattan in 2024.

item.title: Ramping Up Election Attacks, Trump Does Not Let Reality Get in His Way
item.description: President Trump increases his attacks when he fears an election loss. With midterm elections approaching, he has gone into overdrive as Republicans face potential losses.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump Erased the Endangerment Finding. Here Come the Lawsuits.
item.description: The battle is expected to reach the Supreme Court, which is far more conservative today than it was when the measure was established.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump announced on Thursday that his administration would scrap the endangerment finding.

item.title: The Strangeness of Epstein’s Birthday Book
item.description: Of all the materials that have surfaced from the Epstein files, the infamous birthday book may be one of the strangest, argues the Opinion columnist Ezra Klein. He speaks with the journalist Anand Giridharadas on “The Ezra Klein Show” about what the birthday book reveals. “There’s like a cloud of common sense about who this guy is,” says Giridharadas. “That’s what’s so interesting.”
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Another Missed Deadline Casts Doubt on Colorado River Cooperation
item.description: After two years of negotiations, seven states are no closer to agreeing on reduced water use. The stalemate could soon land in court.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance

media:content.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Lake Powell last July. Officials said that flows into the lake this year are 52 percent less than average, potentially rendering the dam unable to produce hydroelectric power by December.

item.title: First U.S. Troops Land in Nigeria for Trump-Led Christian Mission
item.description: The deployment follows months of escalating pressure from President Trump on the African nation, including a surprise missile strike on Christmas Day.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Eric Schmitt and Ismail Alfa
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on ISIS in Nigeria (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Nuhu Gwamna/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A damaged door frame at a church in Nigeria, where worshipers were kidnapped after being attacked by gunmen, in Kurmin Wali, Kaduna, last month.

item.title: What the Epstein Files Make Very Clear
item.description: One thing is clear from the 3.5 million pages of documentation released from the Epstein files: the source of Jeffrey Epstein’s power among a certain elite class in America. “What has come into clear view is the infrastructure of Epstein’s power, and maybe through that the infrastructure of modern power and elite networks more generally,” the Opinion columnist Ezra Klein says.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Who Is Jeremy Carl, Trump’s Nominee to Lead the State Department?
item.description: Jeremy Carl, President Trump’s nominee to lead the State Department’s outreach to international organizations, had a rough confirmation hearing, but he stood by his views on “whiteness.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady

media:content.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jeremy Carl, nominee to be an Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, at a U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington D.C., this week.

item.title: What a Times Reporter on an Antarctica Expedition Eats in a Day
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong has spent more than a month on a South Korean ship in Antarctica with nearly 40 scientists from around the world. Here’s everything he eats in a day.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Leila Medina, Sutton Raphael, Rebecca Suner and Stephanie Swart

item.title: The Government Is Set to Partially Shut Down, Again
item.description: Also, Gisèle Pelicot shares her story. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times

item.title: Ilia Malinin’s catastrophic free skate: ‘I blew it.’
item.description: Malinin, the heavy favorite to win gold, fell twice during his final routine and finished 8th.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather, Doug Mills and Vincent Alban

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Four Killed in Plane Crash Near Steamboat Springs, Colo.
item.description: The plane crashed in remote mountain terrain at about 12:20 a.m. on Friday “under unknown circumstances,” according to the National Transportation Safety Board.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A small plane crashed in a remote wilderness area south of Steamboat Springs, Colo., early on Friday morning.

item.title: After a Harrowing Water Rescue, Baby Is Delivered on Mother’s Birthday
item.description: Shedly Apollon was on her way to a prenatal massage when she started to feel faint while on the road. Her car veered off the highway and into a lake.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: Bob Croft, Who Dived Deep Into the Ocean on a Single Breath, Dies at 91
item.description: His derring-do and unusual lung capacity led him to make record-breaking dives of more than 200 feet into the Atlantic without wearing a scuba tank or fins.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.N. Condemns U.S. Measures Halting Oil Deliveries to Cuba
item.description: The measures were installed last month by the Trump administration after the U.S. captured Nicolás Maduro and seized control of Venezuela’s oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Ramon Espinosa/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A street in Santa Cruz del Norte, Cuba, this month during a scheduled outage as part of energy rationing.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Said to Raise Billions in First Pledges for Gaza
item.description: The United Arab Emirates and the United States have each committed more than $1 billion to President Trump’s new international initiative, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Children collecting paper and plastic at a garbage dump in Gaza last month. Vast sections of the territory were destroyed in the war.

item.title: How the Designer Todd Snyder Gets Ready for New York Fashion Week
item.description: The menswear leader sketches over French fries, then dashes to the office to see one of his favorite models bring dozens of his looks to life.
item.dc:creator: Addie Morfoot

media:content.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times

item.title: The Mutually Beneficial Ties Between Jeffrey Epstein and Thorbjorn Jagland
item.description: Thorbjorn Jagland, a former prime minister of Norway who led the Nobel Committee, promised influence, and the disgraced financier had gifts to give, new emails show.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Henrik Pryser Libell

media:content.media:credit: Stian Lysberg Solum/NTB, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Thorbjorn Jagland, center left, a former prime minister of Norway, in Oslo on Thursday. A recently released tranche of emails revealed his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein.
